Byzantine-resilient Federated Learning With Adaptivity to Data Heterogeneity

Shiyuan Zuo, Xingrun Yan, Rongfei Fan, Han Hu, Hangguan Shan, and Tony Q. S. Quek S.¬†Zuo, X.¬†Yan, and R.¬†Fan are with the School of Cyberspace Science and Technology, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China (e-mail: {zuoshiyuan, 3220221473, fanrongfei}@bit.edu.cn); H.¬†Hu is with the School of Information and Electronics, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China (e-mail: hhu@bit.edu.cn); H.¬†Shan is with the College of Information Science and Electronic Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, China, and also with Zhejiang Provincial Key Laboratory of Information Processing, Communication and Networking, Hangzhou, China (e- mail: hshan@zju.edu.cn); T. Abstract

This paper deals with federated learning (FL) in the presence of malicious Byzantine attacks and data heterogeneity. A novel Robust Average Gradient Algorithm (RAGA) is proposed, which leverages the geometric median for aggregation and can freely select the round number for local updating. Different from most existing resilient approaches, which perform convergence analysis based on strongly-convex loss function or homogeneously distributed dataset, we conduct convergence analysis for not only strongly-convex but also non-convex loss function over heterogeneous dataset. According to our theoretical analysis, as long as the fraction of dataset from malicious users is less than half, RAGA can achieve convergence at rate ùí™‚Äã(1/T2/3‚àíŒ¥)ùí™1superscriptùëá23ùõø\displaystyle\mathcal{O}({1}/{T^{2/3-\delta}}) where Tùëá\displaystyle T is the iteration number and Œ¥‚àà(0,2/3)ùõø023\displaystyle\delta\in(0,2/3) for non-convex loss function, and at linear rate for strongly-convex loss function. Moreover, stationary point or global optimal solution is proved to obtainable as data heterogeneity vanishes. Experimental results corroborate the robustness of RAGA to Byzantine attacks and verifies the advantage of RAGA over baselines on convergence performance under various intensity of Byzantine attacks, for heterogeneous dataset.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, Byzantine attack, data heterogeneity, robust aggregation, convergence analysis.

I Introduction

The rapid growth of intelligent applications in recent decade promotes a broad adoption of them on various devices or equipments, such as mobile phones, wearable devices, and autonomous vehicles, etc [1, 2, 3]. To enable one intelligent application, raw data from various subscribed users has to be trained together to generate a uniform model. From the perspective of subscribed users, who may distribute broadly, it has a risk of privacy leakage if they offload their raw data to a central server for training [4, 5]. Federated learning (FL) is a distributed training framework and has emerged as a promising solution for this dilemma [6, 7]. In FL, model training is completed by exchanging something about model parameters, such as the model parameter itself or the gradient of loss function with model parameters, between each involving user and one central server iteratively. In each round of iteration, the central server aggregates the model parameters from every user and subsequently broadcasts the aggregated one to all the users. After receiving the broadcasted model parameter, each user performs the role of local updating based on its own data. In such a procedure, there is no exchange of raw data between any user and the central server [8, 9].

However, distributed training like FL has to face robust issue because of the involvement of multiple users. To be specific, due to data corruption, device malfunctioning, or malicious attacks at some users, the information about the model parameter to be uploaded to the central server by these abnormal users may deviate from the expected one [10, 11]. In such a case, the group of abnormal users are called as Byzantine users, and the action of Byzantine users is referred to as Byzantine attacks [12, 13]. As a comparison, the group of normal users are called as Honest users. For a Byzantine attack, it is general to assume the uncertainty of the identity and the population of Byzantine users. What is more, the attack initiated by Byzantine users could be arbitrarily malicious [14, 15]. With such a setup, the training performance of FL will be surely degraded and aggregation strategies resistant to Byzantine attacks have been concerned in literature [16].

On the other hand, the training process of FL also faces the challenges of data heterogeneity among multiple users. This heterogeneity comes from the diverse distribution of local data at multiple users, since the local data may be collected by each FL user under its specific environment, habit, or preference [17]. In such a case, data distributions over multiple users are always assumed to be non independently and identically distributed (non-IID). The presence of data heterogeneity has already been demonstrated to cause local drift of user model, and thus, degradation of the global model‚Äôs performance. How to be adaptive to data heterogeneity is also an important issue and has been studied extensively in the area of FL [18].

I-A Related Works

In related works, aggregation strategies are designed to be robust to the Byzantine attack under various setup of system assumptions, whose performance is then justified by convergence analysis and/or experimental results. The system assumptions usually relate to the nature of the data (IID or non-IID), the nature of the loss function (strongly-convex or non-convex), and the way of local updating (one-step or multiple steps), etc. For these assumptions, the data heterogeneity and non-convex loss function make FL framework more general, and multiple steps of local updating waives each user from frequent communication with the central server. The Byzantine-resilient aggregation strategies in the literature of FL under diverse system assumptions have been summarized in Table I.

As of the aggregation strategies in related literature, by leveraging median [16], trimmed mean [19], or iterative filtering [20], the associated FL system can tolerate a small fraction of Byzantine users. To be more robust to Byzantine attacks, some methods such as Robust Aggregating Normalized Gradient Method (RANGE) [21], a Huber Loss Minimization [22], semi verified mean estimation [23], Krum [24], Federated Learning Over the Air (FLOA) [25], and Robust Stochastic Aggregation (RSA) [26], have been proposed. Specifically, RANGE takes the coordinate-wise median of uploaded stochastic gradients as the aggregated one. [22] improve the trimmed mean on non-IID datasets by utilizing a multi-dimensional Huber loss function to aggregate uploaded messages. [23] leverges semi verified mean estimation to filter out the messages from Byzantine attackers before aggregation. Krum selects a stochastic gradient as the global one, which has the shortest cumulative distance from a group of stochastic gradients that are most closely distributed, FLOA requires each user to normalize the associated local gradient to be a vector with zero mean and unit variance before offloading it to the central server, RSA penalizes the difference between local model parameters and global model parameters to isolate Byzantine users.

Although the above aggregation strategies can be resistant to Byzantine attacks at some extent, they may still fail to work in front of heavy Byzantine attacks without identifying the Byzantine attacker: The attacks with the fraction of Byzantine users being large or the amplitude of uploaded vectors by Byzantine users being high. Recently, geometric median appears as a good candidate for aggregation because of its ability to naturally tolerate a larger fraction of strong Byzantine attacks [30]. Based on geometric median, some algorithms such as Robust Federated Aggregation (RFA) [27], Byzantine attack resilient distributed Stochastic Average Gradient Algorithm (Byrd-SAGA) [28], and Byzantine-RObust Aggregation with gradient Difference Compression And STochastic variance reduction (BROADCAST) [29], have been proposed. To be specific, geometric median is leveraged to aggregate the uploaded vectors for RFA, Byrd-SAGA, and BROADCAST. Differently, each user in RFA selects the trimmed mean of the model parameters over multiple local updating as the uploaded vector, while Byrd-SAGA and BROADCAST utilize the SAGA [31] method to generate the vectors for aggregation first and then upload them in a lossless or compressive way.

In aforementioned Byzantine-resilient aggregation strategies, there is little work claimed to be adaptive to data heterogeneity, which however is a non-negligible issue. RFA in [27] is an exception. However, RFA only investigates strongly-convex loss function. With such a convexity setup, RFA shows that it is can converge to a neighborhood of the optimal solution only if the number of local updates for each involving user is larger than then a threshold so as to fulfill a necessary inequality. However, this restricts the flexibility of selecting the number of local updates and maybe computationally intensive when these users have limited computation capability.

I-B Motivations and Contributions

In this paper we investigate Byzantine-resilient FL with adaptivity to data heterogeneity, which was rarely studied in literature. Different from RFA, which is the unique work dealing with both Byzantine attack and data heterogeneity in FL by now but only considers strongly-convex loss function, we investigate not only strongly-convex but also non-convex loss function. Moreover, with regard to strongly-convex loss function, not like RFA that requires the step number of local updates to be above some threshold (which is a prerequisite for promising convergence in RFA), we assume arbitrary selection of it, which is more general. With our featured system setup, we propose a novel FL structure, RAGA. Specifically, the RAGA leverages the geometric median to aggregate the local gradients offloaded by the users after multiple rounds of local updating. Associated analysis of convergence and robustness are then followed for both non-convex and strongly-convex loss functions. Our main contributions are summarized as follows:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Algorithmically, we propose a new FL aggregation strategy, named RAGA, which has the flexibility of arbitrary selection of local update‚Äôs step number, and is robust to both Byzantine attack and data heterogeneity.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Theoretically, we established a convergence guarantee for our proposed RAGA under not only non-convex but also strongly-convex loss function. Through rigorous proof, we show that the established convergence can be promised as long as the fraction of dataset from Byzantine users is less than half. The achievable convergence rate can be at ùí™‚Äã(1/T2/3‚àíŒ¥)ùí™1superscriptùëá23ùõø\displaystyle\mathcal{O}({1}/{T^{2/3-\delta}}) where Tùëá\displaystyle T is the iteration number and Œ¥‚àà(0,2/3)ùõø023\displaystyle\delta\in(0,2/3) for non-convex loss function, and at linear for strongly-convex loss function. Moreover, stationary point and global optimal solution are shown to be obtainable as data heterogeneity vanishes, for non-convex and strongly-convex loss function, respectively.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Empirically, we conduct extensive experiments to evaluate the performance of our proposed RAGA. With non-IID dataset, our proposed RAGA is verified to be robust to various Byzantine attack level. Moreover, compared with baseline methods, our proposed RAGA can achieve higher test accuracy and lower training loss.

I-C Organization and Notation

The rest of this paper is organized as follows: Section II introduces the system model and formulates the problem to be solved in this paper, Section III presents our proposed RAGA. In Section IV, the analysis of convergence and robustness for our proposed RAGA under non-convex and strongly-convex loss function are disclosed. Experimental results are illustrated in Section V, followed by conclusion remarks in Section VI.

In traditional FL, iterative interactions between a group of MùëÄ\displaystyle M users and a central server are performed to update the gradient parameter ‚àáF‚Äã(ùíò)‚àáùêπùíò\displaystyle\nabla F(\bm{w}) until convergence. For tùë°\displaystyle tth round of iteration, a conventional operation procedure can be given as the following steps:

Step 1 (Local Update): For mùëö\displaystyle mth user, it calculates the local gradient parameter ‚àáFm‚Äã(ùíòt)‚àásubscriptùêπùëösuperscriptùíòùë°\displaystyle\nabla F_{m}(\bm{w}^{t}) from its local dateset ùíÆmsubscriptùíÆùëö\displaystyle\mathcal{S}_{m} and global model parameter ùíòtsuperscriptùíòùë°\displaystyle\bm{w}^{t}.

Step 2 (Aggregation and Broadcasting): Each user sends its local gradient parameter ‚àáFm‚Äã(ùíòt)‚àásubscriptùêπùëösuperscriptùíòùë°\displaystyle\nabla F_{m}(\bm{w}^{t}) to the central server. The central server then aggregates all the local gradient vectors into a common one, denoted as ùíòt+1superscriptùíòùë°1\displaystyle\bm{w}^{t+1}, as follows,

ùíòt+1=ùíòt‚àíŒ∑‚ãÖ‚àëm=1M‚àáFm‚Äã(ùíòt),superscriptùíòùë°1superscriptùíòùë°‚ãÖùúÇsuperscriptsubscriptùëö1ùëÄ‚àásubscriptùêπùëösuperscriptùíòùë°\bm{w}^{t+1}=\bm{w}^{t}-\eta\cdot\sum_{m=1}^{M}\nabla F_{m}(\bm{w}^{t}), (11)

then the central server broadcasts ùíòt+1superscriptùíòùë°1\displaystyle\bm{w}^{t+1} to all the users.

With some combination of previously claimed assumptions, the above iterative operation may help to reach the optimal or convergent solution of Problem 1 if each user sends trustworthy message to the central server. However, under Byzantine attacks, the main challenge of solving Problem 1 comes from the fact that the Byzantine attackers can collude and send arbitrary malicious messages to the central server so as to bias the optimization process. We aspire to develop a robust FL algorithm to address this issue in next section.

III Proposed Aggregation Strategy: Robustness Average Gradient Algorithm (RAGA)

Before the introduction of the RAGA, we first explain the scenario of Byzantine attack. Assume there are Bùêµ\displaystyle B Byzantine users out of MùëÄ\displaystyle M users, which compose the set of ‚Ñ¨‚Ñ¨\displaystyle\mathcal{B}. Any Byzantine user can send an arbitrary vector ‚ãÜ,‚ãÜ‚àà‚Ñùp\displaystyle\star,\star\in\mathbb{R}^{p} to the central server. Suppose ùíõmtsuperscriptsubscriptùíõùëöùë°\displaystyle\bm{z}_{m}^{t} is the real vector uploaded by mùëö\displaystyle mth user to the central server in tùë°\displaystyle tth round of iteration, then there is

ùíõmt={ùíàmt,m‚àà‚Ñ≥‚àñ‚Ñ¨‚ãÜ,m‚àà‚Ñ¨\bm{z}_{m}^{t}=\left\{\begin{aligned} &{\bm{g}_{m}^{t},}&&{m\in\mathcal{M}\setminus\mathcal{B}}\\ &{\bm{\star},}&&{m\in\mathcal{B}}\end{aligned}\right. (12)

where gmtsuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëöùë°\displaystyle g_{m}^{t} denotes the vector to be uploaded by honest user (m‚àà‚Ñ≥‚àñ‚Ñ¨ùëö‚Ñ≥‚Ñ¨\displaystyle m\in\mathcal{M}\setminus\mathcal{B}). Additionally, we also assume ‚àëm‚àà‚Ñ¨Sm<12‚Äã‚àëm‚àà‚Ñ≥Smsubscriptùëö‚Ñ¨subscriptùëÜùëö12subscriptùëö‚Ñ≥subscriptùëÜùëö\displaystyle\sum_{m\in\mathcal{B}}S_{m}<\frac{1}{2}\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}}S_{m}. In related works [28], by implicitly supposing SmsubscriptùëÜùëö\displaystyle S_{m} to be identical for every m‚àà‚Ñ≥ùëö‚Ñ≥\displaystyle m\in\mathcal{M}, it is usually assumed B<12‚ÄãMùêµ12ùëÄ\displaystyle B<\frac{1}{2}M, which is a special realization of our assumption.

To reduce communication burden due to frequent interactions between MùëÄ\displaystyle M users and the central server and overcome the Byzantine attacks, we propose the RAGA, which runs multi-local updates and aggregates all the uploaded vectors in a robust way. Specifically, in tùë°\displaystyle tth round of iteration:

Step 1 (Multi-Local Update): For any honest user mùëö\displaystyle m, m‚àà‚Ñ≥‚àñ‚Ñ¨ùëö‚Ñ≥‚Ñ¨\displaystyle m\in\mathcal{M}\setminus\mathcal{B}. Denote ùíòmt,ksuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëöùë°ùëò\displaystyle\bm{w}_{m}^{t,k} as the local model parameter of mùëö\displaystyle mth user for kùëò\displaystyle kth update and Œ∑mt,ksuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëöùë°ùëò\displaystyle\eta_{m}^{t,k} as the associated learning rate. By implementing stochastic gradient descend (SGD) method, there is

ùíòmt,k=ùíòmt,k‚àí1‚àíŒ∑mt,k‚ãÖ‚àáFm‚Äã(ùíòmt,k‚àí1;Œæmt,k),k=1,2,‚Ä¶,Ktformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëöùë°ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëöùë°ùëò1‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptùúÇùëöùë°ùëò‚àásubscriptùêπùëösuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëöùë°ùëò1superscriptsubscriptùúâùëöùë°ùëòùëò12‚Ä¶superscriptùêæùë°\displaystyle\displaystyle\bm{w}_{m}^{t,k}=\bm{w}_{m}^{t,k-1}-\eta_{m}^{t,k}\cdot\nabla F_{m}(\bm{w}_{m}^{t,k-1};\xi_{m}^{t,k}),k=1,2,\dots,K^{t} (13)

where Œæmt,ksuperscriptsubscriptùúâùëöùë°ùëò\displaystyle\xi_{m}^{t,k} is a randomly selected subset of dataset ùíÆmsubscriptùíÆùëö\displaystyle\mathcal{S}_{m} and ùíòmt,0=ùíòtsuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëöùë°0superscriptùíòùë°\displaystyle\bm{w}_{m}^{t,0}=\bm{w}^{t}. The ùíòtsuperscriptùíòùë°\displaystyle\bm{w}^{t} is received from t‚àí1ùë°1\displaystyle t-1 round of iteration. Specially, for the sake of robustness and convergence, we set ùíõmt=ùíàmt=1Kt‚Äã‚àëk=1Kt‚àáFm‚Äã(ùíòmt,k‚àí1;Œæmt,k)superscriptsubscriptùíõùëöùë°superscriptsubscriptùíàùëöùë°1superscriptùêæùë°superscriptsubscriptùëò1superscriptùêæùë°‚àásubscriptùêπùëösuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëöùë°ùëò1superscriptsubscriptùúâùëöùë°ùëò\displaystyle\bm{z}_{m}^{t}=\bm{g}_{m}^{t}=\frac{1}{K^{t}}\sum_{k=1}^{K^{t}}\nabla F_{m}(\bm{w}_{m}^{t,k-1};\xi_{m}^{t,k}) for m‚àà‚Ñ≥‚àñ‚Ñ¨ùëö‚Ñ≥‚Ñ¨\displaystyle m\in\mathcal{M}\setminus\mathcal{B}.

Step 2 (Aggregation and Broadcasting): For the mùëö\displaystyle mth user, it uploads its own vector ùíõmtsuperscriptsubscriptùíõùëöùë°\displaystyle\bm{z}_{m}^{t} to the central server for m‚àà‚Ñ≥ùëö‚Ñ≥\displaystyle m\in\mathcal{M}. To ensure the robustness of the FL system, we use the numerical geometric median of all the uploaded vectors, which is defined as

ùíòt+1superscriptùíòùë°1\displaystyle\displaystyle\bm{w}^{t+1} =ùíòt‚àíŒ∑t‚ãÖùíõtabsentsuperscriptùíòùë°‚ãÖsuperscriptùúÇùë°superscriptùíõùë°\displaystyle\displaystyle=\bm{w}^{t}-\eta^{t}\cdot\bm{z}^{t} (14)

where Œ∑tsuperscriptùúÇùë°\displaystyle\eta^{t} represents the global learning rate for tùë°\displaystyle tth round of iteration and ùíõtsuperscriptùíõùë°\displaystyle\bm{z}^{t} represents the numerical estimation of the geometric median of {ùíõmt|m‚àà‚Ñ≥}conditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptùíõùëöùë°ùëö‚Ñ≥\displaystyle\{\bm{z}_{m}^{t}|m\in\mathcal{M}\}, i.e., geomed‚Äã({ùíõmt|m‚àà‚Ñ≥})geomedconditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptùíõùëöùë°ùëö‚Ñ≥\displaystyle{\rm geomed}\left(\{\bm{z}_{m}^{t}|m\in\mathcal{M}\}\right). The geomed‚Äã({ùíõmt|m‚àà‚Ñ≥})geomedconditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptùíõùëöùë°ùëö‚Ñ≥\displaystyle{\rm geomed}\left(\{\bm{z}_{m}^{t}|m\in\mathcal{M}\}\right) in this paper is defined as

geomed‚Äã({ùíõmt|m‚àà‚Ñ≥})‚âúùíõt,‚àó=arg‚Å°miny‚Äã‚àëi=1MSi‚àëj=1MSj‚Äã‚à•y‚àíùíõit‚à•.‚âúgeomedconditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptùíõùëöùë°ùëö‚Ñ≥superscriptùíõùë°subscriptùë¶superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÄsubscriptùëÜùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÄsubscriptùëÜùëódelimited-‚à•‚à•ùë¶superscriptsubscriptùíõùëñùë°\displaystyle\displaystyle{\rm geomed}\left(\{\bm{z}_{m}^{t}|m\in\mathcal{M}\}\right)\triangleq\bm{z}^{t,*}=\arg\min_{y}\sum_{i=1}^{M}\frac{S_{i}}{\sum_{j=1}^{M}S_{j}}\left\lVert y-\bm{z}_{i}^{t}\right\rVert. (15)

The problem in (15) is actually a convex optimization problem and an œµitalic-œµ\displaystyle\epsilon-optimal solution is obtainable by resorting to Weiszfeld algorithm [34]. Hence the ùíõtsuperscriptùíõùë°\displaystyle\bm{z}^{t} fulfills the following condition

‚àëi=1MSi‚àëj=1MSj‚Äã‚à•ùíõt‚àíùíõit‚à•‚©Ω‚àëi=1MSi‚àëj=1MSj‚Äã‚à•ùíõt,‚àó‚àíùíõit‚à•+œµ,superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÄsubscriptùëÜùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÄsubscriptùëÜùëódelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùíõùë°superscriptsubscriptùíõùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÄsubscriptùëÜùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÄsubscriptùëÜùëódelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùíõùë°superscriptsubscriptùíõùëñùë°italic-œµ\displaystyle\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{M}\frac{S_{i}}{\sum_{j=1}^{M}S_{j}}\left\lVert\bm{z}^{t}-\bm{z}_{i}^{t}\right\rVert\leqslant\sum_{i=1}^{M}\frac{S_{i}}{\sum_{j=1}^{M}S_{j}}\left\lVert\bm{z}^{t,*}-\bm{z}_{i}^{t}\right\rVert+\epsilon, (16)

and is also denoted as geomed‚Äã({ùíõmt|m‚àà‚Ñ≥},œµ)geomedconditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptùíõùëöùë°ùëö‚Ñ≥italic-œµ\displaystyle{\rm geomed}\left(\{\bm{z}_{m}^{t}|m\in\mathcal{M}\},\epsilon\right) in the sequel. Then the central server broadcasts the global model parameter ùíòt+1subscriptùíòùë°1\displaystyle\bm{w}_{t+1} to all the users for preparing the calculation in t+1ùë°1\displaystyle t+1 round of iteration.

Based on the above description, the RAGA is conceptually illustrated in Fig 1 and summarized in Algorithm 1.

IV Analysis of Convergence and Robustness

In this section, we provide theoretical analysis of the robustness and convergence of the RAGA under Byzantine attacks under two cases of loss function‚Äôs convexity.

IV-A Case \@slowromancapi@: With Lipschitz Continuity Only for Loss Function

Œ±m=Sm‚àëj=1MSj,CŒ±=‚àëm‚àà‚Ñ≥‚àñ‚Ñ¨Œ±m,formulae-sequencesubscriptùõºùëösubscriptùëÜùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÄsubscriptùëÜùëósubscriptùê∂ùõºsubscriptùëö‚Ñ≥‚Ñ¨subscriptùõºùëö\displaystyle\displaystyle\alpha_{m}=\frac{S_{m}}{\sum_{j=1}^{M}S_{j}},C_{\alpha}=\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}\setminus\mathcal{B}}\alpha_{m}, (17)

    (4‚ÄãL3‚Äã(K‚àí1)‚Äã(2‚ÄãK‚àí1)‚Äã(CŒ±)2‚Äã(G2+œÉ2)3‚ÄãŒº‚Äã(2‚ÄãCŒ±‚àí1)2‚Äã(T‚ÄãK)2‚ÄãŒ≤‚Äã1‚àí(Œ≥)T1‚àíŒ≥‚Äã(Œ∑)3)4superscriptùêø3ùêæ12ùêæ1superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùõº2superscriptùê∫2superscriptùúé23ùúásuperscript2subscriptùê∂ùõº12superscriptùëáùêæ2ùõΩ1superscriptùõæùëá1ùõæsuperscriptùúÇ3\displaystyle\displaystyle\left(\frac{4L^{3}(K-1)(2K-1)(C_{\alpha})^{2}(G^{2}+\sigma^{2})}{3\mu(2C_{\alpha}-1)^{2}(TK)^{2\beta}}\frac{1-(\gamma)^{T}}{1-\gamma}(\eta)^{3}\right)
    +(L‚Äã(Œ≥)T‚àí12‚Äãùîº‚Äã{‚à•ùíò1‚àíùíò‚àó‚à•2})+8‚ÄãL‚Äã(CŒ±)2‚ÄãŒ∏+œµ2‚ÄãL+4‚ÄãL‚Äã(CŒ±)2‚ÄãœÉ2Œº‚Äã(2‚ÄãCŒ±‚àí1)2‚Äã1‚àí(Œ≥)T1‚àíŒ≥‚ÄãŒ∑ùêøsuperscriptùõæùëá12ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùíò1superscriptùíò28ùêøsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùõº2ùúÉsuperscriptitalic-œµ2ùêø4ùêøsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùõº2superscriptùúé2ùúásuperscript2subscriptùê∂ùõº121superscriptùõæùëá1ùõæùúÇ\displaystyle\displaystyle+\left(\frac{L(\gamma)^{T-1}}{2}\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\lVert\bm{w}^{1}-\bm{w}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}\right\}\right)+\frac{8L(C_{\alpha})^{2}\theta+\epsilon^{2}L+4L(C_{\alpha})^{2}\sigma^{2}}{\mu(2C_{\alpha}-1)^{2}}\frac{1-(\gamma)^{T}}{1-\gamma}\eta (28)

    which also convergences to (27) but at a rate ùí™‚Äã((Œ≥)T‚àí1+(T‚ÄãK)‚àí2‚ÄãŒ≤)ùí™superscriptùõæùëá1superscriptùëáùêæ2ùõΩ\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\left((\gamma)^{T-1}+(TK)^{-2\beta}\right). This rate can be adjusted by Œ≤ùõΩ\displaystyle\beta and would be linear when Œ≤‚àùTproportional-toùõΩùëá\displaystyle\beta\propto T.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Compared with the discussion in Remark 1 that works for non-convex loss function, we can obtain zero optimality gap as Œ∏ùúÉ\displaystyle\theta, œµitalic-œµ\displaystyle\epsilon, and œÉùúé\displaystyle\sigma go to zero for strongly-convex loss function in this case, which implies the achievement of global optimal solution rather than stationary point as in Remark 1. Moreover, linear convergence rate is achievable in this case and is faster than the rate ùí™‚Äã(1T2/3‚àíŒ¥)ùí™1superscriptùëá23ùõø\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{T^{2/3-\delta}}\right) as shown in Remark 1.

  • ‚Ä¢

    It is also worthy to note that the above results still hold on the condition that CŒ±>0.5subscriptùê∂ùõº0.5\displaystyle C_{\alpha}>0.5, which promises a strong robustness to Byzantine attacks.

V Experiments

In this section, we conduct experiments to inspect the convergence performance of our proposed RAGA under various system setups together with baseline methods, so as to verify the advantage of RAGA over peers in being robust to Byzantine attacks in front of heterogeneous dataset.

V-A Setup

To carry out experiments, we set up a machine learning environment in PyTorch 2.1.0 on Ubuntu 20.04, powered by two 3090 GPUs.

V-A1 Datasets and Models

We conduct experiments by leveraging two datasets: MNIST and CIFAR10. These two datasets are widely used for learning tasks and are introduced as follows:

  • ‚Ä¢

    MNIST: The MNIST dataset includes a training set and a test set. The training set contains 60000 samples and the test set contains 10000 samples, each sample of which is a 28 √ó\displaystyle\times 28 pixel grayscale image.

  • ‚Ä¢

    CIFAR10: The CIFAR10 dataset is composed of a training set and a test set. The training set contains 50000 samples and the test set contains 10000 samples, where each sample is a 32 √ó\displaystyle\times 32 color image.

For these experiments, we split the above two training sets into MùëÄ\displaystyle M non-IID training sets, which is realized by letting the label of data samples to conform to Dirichlet distribution. The extent of non-IID can be adjusted by tuning the concentration parameter of Dirichlet distribution.

For training problems with non-convex and strongly-convex loss functions, we adopt LeNet and Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) model, respectively. The introduction of these two models are as follows:

  • ‚Ä¢

    LeNet: The LeNet model is one of the earliest published convolutional neural networks. For the experiments, we are going to train a LeNet model with two convolutional layers, two pooling layers, and one fully connected layer like in [35]. Cross-entropy function is taken as the training loss.

  • ‚Ä¢

    MLP: The MLP model is a machine learning model based on Feedforward Neural Network that can achieve high-level feature extraction and classification. To promise strong convexity for the loss function, we configure the MLP model to be with only fully connected layers like in [36] and take the cross-entropy function as the training loss.

V-A2 Hyperparameters

We assume M=50ùëÄ50\displaystyle M=50 and the batchsize of all the experiments is 512. The error tolerance œµitalic-œµ\displaystyle\epsilon for numerically working out geometric median is œµ=1√ó10‚àí5italic-œµ1superscript105\displaystyle\epsilon=1\times 10^{-5}. The concentration parameter of Dirichlet distribution is 0.6. In default, the iteration number T=1000ùëá1000\displaystyle T=1000 for the MNIST dataset, and T=10000ùëá10000\displaystyle T=10000 for the CIFAR10 dataset. The round number of local updates Ktsuperscriptùêæùë°\displaystyle K^{t} is 3 for RFA and RAGA. The Byzantine attacks are selected as the Gaussian attack, which obeys standard normal distribution. 1‚àíCŒ±1subscriptùê∂ùõº\displaystyle 1-C_{\alpha} are used to indicate the intensity level of Byzantine attacks. In terms of the learning rate, we adopt default setup as shown in corresponding papers for baseline methods. For RAGA, the learning rate Œ∑mt,k=Œ∑t=T/(100‚Äãt+10‚ÄãT)subscriptsuperscriptùúÇùë°ùëòùëösuperscriptùúÇùë°ùëá100ùë°10ùëá\displaystyle\eta^{t,k}_{m}=\eta^{t}={T}/{(100t+10T)}.

V-A3 Baselines

The convergence performance of four algorithms: RAGA, FedAvg [17], Byrd-SAGA [28], and RFA [27] are compared. For the latter three algorithms, FedAvg is renowned in traditional FL but does not concern Byzantine attack and can be taken as a performance metric when there is no Byzantine attack, Byrd-SAGA only executes one local updating in each round of iteration, and RFA selects the trimmed mean of the model parameters over multiple local updating as the uploaded vector. It is worthy to note that there is another Byzantine-resilient FL algorithm in related works: BROADCAST [29]. We do not show the performance of it because BROADCAST is very similar with Byrd-SAGA and only differs from Byrd-SAGA by uploading vector from each user to the central server in a compressive, rather than lossless way like in Byrd-SAGA.

V-A4 Performance Metrics

To assess the convergence performance, we measure the test accuracy, the convergence speed and the training loss. An algorithm would be better if its test accuracy is higher, convergence speed is faster, or training loss is lower.

V-B Convergence Performance

We start from Table II, which shows the test accuracy of these four algorithms under different intensity levels of Byzantine attack for various datasets and learning models. From Table II, we see that RAGA can mostly achieve the highest test accuracy under Byzantine attacks. Even there is no Byzantine attack, in which case FedAvg performs best, RAGA ranks the second in most cases and is very close to FedAvg. Additionally, as the intensity level of Byzantine attack grows from 0 to 0.4, in which case nearly half of training data of the whole system is corrupted by Byzantine users, we see RAGA degrades little, which verifies the robustness of RAGA to Byzantine attacks.

Fig. 2 and Fig. 3 illustrate the convergence performance of the four comparing algorithms versus iteration number, by means of test accuracy and training loss, in the training task of LeNet and MLP respectively, for CIFAR10 dataset. From Fig. 2 and Fig. 3, we can observe that both RAGA and FedAvg act similarly and perform better than other algorithms when there is no Byzantine attack. With the existence of Byzantine attack, FedAvg performs badly as it does not take Byzantine attack into account and RAGA becomes the one that outperforms all the other algorithms, both in terms of test accuracy and training loss.

Fig. 4 and Fig. 5 repeat the experiment as shown in Fig. 2 and Fig. 3 but for a different dataset, i.e., MNIST dataset. From Fig. 4 and Fig. 5, when there is no Byzantine attack, we can see that both RAGA and FedAvg have the best convergence performance but RAGA is more stable than FedAvg for the training task of LeNet model. As Byzantine attack comes up, FedAvg is very sensitive to the Byzantine attack and degrades a lot. In contrast, RAGA is always the best one compared with all the other algorithms, no matter how strong the Byzantine attack is.

In summary, through the above numerical experiments, it can be seen that the RAGA not only defeats its opponents at different levels of Byzantine attack, but also acts well and has a comparable performance with FedAvg that performs best when there is no Byzantine attack. It is also worthy to mention that RAGA achieves a nearly unchanged convergence performance no matter how strong the Byzantine attack is. Last but not least, all the above results are obtained based on non-IID datasets.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we propose a novel FL aggregation strategy, RAGA, so as to be robust to Byzantine attacks and data heterogeneity. In our proposed RAGA, geometric median is leveraged for aggregation and the round number for local updating can be selected freely. Rigorous proofs disclose that our proposed RAGA can achieve convergence at rate ùí™‚Äã(1/T2/3‚àíŒ¥)ùí™1superscriptùëá23ùõø\displaystyle\mathcal{O}({1}/{T^{2/3-\delta}}) with Œ¥‚àà(0,2/3)ùõø023\displaystyle\delta\in(0,2/3) for non-convex loss function and at linear rate for strongly-convex loss function, so long as the fraction of dataset from malicious users is less than half. Experimental results based on heterogeneous datasets show that RAGA performs steadily and keeps on an advantage on convergence performance over baseline methods under various intensity of Byzantine attacks.

    the inequality (41a) holds according to Assumption 1;

    the inequality (41c) comes from Cauchy-Schwarz inequality (a1‚Äãb1+a2‚Äãb2+a3‚Äãb3+‚ãØ+an‚Äãbn)2‚©Ω(a12+a22+a32+‚ãØ+an2)‚Äã(b12+b22+b32+‚ãØ+bn2)superscriptsubscriptùëé1subscriptùëè1subscriptùëé2subscriptùëè2subscriptùëé3subscriptùëè3‚ãØsubscriptùëéùëõsubscriptùëèùëõ2superscriptsubscriptùëé12superscriptsubscriptùëé22superscriptsubscriptùëé32‚ãØsuperscriptsubscriptùëéùëõ2superscriptsubscriptùëè12superscriptsubscriptùëè22superscriptsubscriptùëè32‚ãØsuperscriptsubscriptùëèùëõ2\displaystyle(a_{1}b_{1}+a_{2}b_{2}+a_{3}b_{3}+\dots+a_{n}b_{n})^{2}\leqslant(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+a_{3}^{2}+\dots+a_{n}^{2})(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+b_{3}^{2}+\dots+b_{n}^{2});

  • ‚Ä¢

    the inequality (41d) can be derived from Assumptions 3, 4 and 5.

Combining (20), (C), (40) and (41), we obtain the following inequality

ùîº‚Äã{‚à•ùíõt‚àí‚àáF‚Äã(ùíòt)‚à•2}‚©ΩŒît+8‚ÄãœÉ2‚Äã(CŒ±)2(2‚ÄãCŒ±‚àí1)2+2‚Äãœµ2(2‚ÄãCŒ±‚àí1)2ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùíõùë°‚àáùêπsuperscriptùíòùë°2superscriptŒîùë°8superscriptùúé2superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùõº2superscript2subscriptùê∂ùõº122superscriptitalic-œµ2superscript2subscriptùê∂ùõº12\displaystyle\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\lVert\bm{z}^{t}-\nabla F(\bm{w}^{t})\right\rVert^{2}\right\}\leqslant\Delta^{t}+\frac{8\sigma^{2}(C_{\alpha})^{2}}{(2C_{\alpha}-1)^{2}}+\frac{2\epsilon^{2}}{\left(2C_{\alpha}-1\right)^{2}} (42)

This completes the proof of Lemma 1.

Appendix D Proof of Lemma 2

With Lemma 3, there is

ùîº‚Äã{‚à•ùíõt‚à•2}‚©Ω8‚ÄãCŒ±(2‚ÄãCŒ±‚àí1)2‚Äã‚àëm‚àà‚Ñ≥‚àñ‚Ñ¨Œ±m‚Äãùîº‚Äã‚à•ùíõmt‚à•2+2‚Äãœµ2(2‚ÄãCŒ±‚àí1)2ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùíõùë°28subscriptùê∂ùõºsuperscript2subscriptùê∂ùõº12subscriptùëö‚Ñ≥‚Ñ¨subscriptùõºùëöùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùíõùëöùë°22superscriptitalic-œµ2superscript2subscriptùê∂ùõº12\displaystyle\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\lVert\bm{z}^{t}\right\rVert^{2}\right\}\leqslant\frac{8C_{\alpha}}{(2C_{\alpha}-1)^{2}}\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}\setminus\mathcal{B}}\alpha_{m}\mathbb{E}\left\lVert\bm{z}_{m}^{t}\right\rVert^{2}+\frac{2\epsilon^{2}}{\left(2C_{\alpha}-1\right)^{2}} (43)

For the term ùîº‚Äã{‚à•ùíõmt‚à•2}ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùíõùëöùë°2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\lVert\bm{z}_{m}^{t}\right\rVert^{2}\right\}, m‚àà‚Ñ≥‚àñ‚Ñ¨ùëö‚Ñ≥‚Ñ¨\displaystyle m\in\mathcal{M}\setminus\mathcal{B}, according to Assumptions 3, 4 and 5, we have

ùîº‚Äã{‚à•ùíõmt‚à•2}ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùíõùëöùë°2\displaystyle\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\lVert\bm{z}_{m}^{t}\right\rVert^{2}\right\} =ùîº‚Äã{‚à•1Kt‚Äã‚àëk=1Kt‚àáFm‚Äã(ùíòmt,k‚àí1;Œæmt,k)‚à•2}absentùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•1superscriptùêæùë°superscriptsubscriptùëò1superscriptùêæùë°‚àásubscriptùêπùëösuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëöùë°ùëò1superscriptsubscriptùúâùëöùë°ùëò2\displaystyle\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\lVert\frac{1}{K^{t}}\sum_{k=1}^{K^{t}}\nabla F_{m}(\bm{w}_{m}^{t,k-1};\xi_{m}^{t,k})\right\rVert^{2}\right\} (44a)
‚©Ω1Kt‚Äã‚àëk=1Ktùîº‚Äã{‚à•‚àáFm‚Äã(ùíòmt,k‚àí1;Œæmt,k)‚à•2}absent1superscriptùêæùë°superscriptsubscriptùëò1superscriptùêæùë°ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•‚àásubscriptùêπùëösuperscriptsubscriptùíòùëöùë°ùëò1superscriptsubscriptùúâùëöùë°ùëò2\displaystyle\displaystyle\leqslant\frac{1}{K^{t}}\sum_{k=1}^{K^{t}}\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\lVert\nabla F_{m}(\bm{w}_{m}^{t,k-1};\xi_{m}^{t,k})\right\rVert^{2}\right\} (44b)
‚©ΩG2+œÉ2absentsuperscriptùê∫2superscriptùúé2\displaystyle\displaystyle\leqslant G^{2}+\sigma^{2} (44c)

where the inequality (44b) comes from Cauchy-Schwarz inequality (a1+a2+a3+‚ãØ+an)2‚©Ωn‚Äã(a12+a22+a32+‚ãØ+an2)superscriptsubscriptùëé1subscriptùëé2subscriptùëé3‚ãØsubscriptùëéùëõ2ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëé12superscriptsubscriptùëé22superscriptsubscriptùëé32‚ãØsuperscriptsubscriptùëéùëõ2\displaystyle(a_{1}+a_{2}+a_{3}+\dots+a_{n})^{2}\leqslant n(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+a_{3}^{2}+\dots+a_{n}^{2}). Hence we can get the following inequality

ùîº‚Äã{‚à•ùíõt‚à•2}‚©Ω8‚Äã(CŒ±)2‚Äã(G2+œÉ2)(2‚ÄãCŒ±‚àí1)2+2‚Äãœµ2(2‚ÄãCŒ±‚àí1)2ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùíõùë°28superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùõº2superscriptùê∫2superscriptùúé2superscript2subscriptùê∂ùõº122superscriptitalic-œµ2superscript2subscriptùê∂ùõº12\displaystyle\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\lVert\bm{z}^{t}\right\rVert^{2}\right\}\leqslant\frac{8(C_{\alpha})^{2}(G^{2}+\sigma^{2})}{(2C_{\alpha}-1)^{2}}+\frac{2\epsilon^{2}}{\left(2C_{\alpha}-1\right)^{2}} (45)

Since ùîº‚Äã{‚à•ùíõt‚à•2}‚©æ0ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùíõùë°20\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\lVert\bm{z}^{t}\right\rVert^{2}\right\}\geqslant 0, then there is

0‚©Ωùîº‚Äã{‚à•ùíõt‚à•2}‚©Ω8‚Äã(CŒ±)2‚Äã(G2+œÉ2)(2‚ÄãCŒ±‚àí1)2+2‚Äãœµ2(2‚ÄãCŒ±‚àí1)20ùîºsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùíõùë°28superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùõº2superscriptùê∫2superscriptùúé2superscript2subscriptùê∂ùõº122superscriptitalic-œµ2superscript2subscriptùê∂ùõº12\displaystyle\displaystyle 0\leqslant\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\lVert\bm{z}^{t}\right\rVert^{2}\right\}\leqslant\frac{8(C_{\alpha})^{2}(G^{2}+\sigma^{2})}{(2C_{\alpha}-1)^{2}}+\frac{2\epsilon^{2}}{\left(2C_{\alpha}-1\right)^{2}} (46)

Appendix E Proof of Lemma 3

For the ease of presentation, we denote
ùíõ‚àó=geomed‚Äã({ùíõm|m‚àà‚Ñ≥})superscriptùíõgeomedconditional-setsubscriptùíõùëöùëö‚Ñ≥\displaystyle\bm{z}^{*}={\rm geomed}\left(\{\bm{z}_{m}|m\in\mathcal{M}\}\right) and
ùíõœµ‚àó=geomed‚Äã({ùíõm|m‚àà‚Ñ≥},œµ)superscriptsubscriptùíõitalic-œµgeomedconditional-setsubscriptùíõùëöùëö‚Ñ≥italic-œµ\displaystyle\bm{z}_{\epsilon}^{*}={\rm geomed}\left(\{\bm{z}_{m}|m\in\mathcal{M}\},\epsilon\right), then there is

‚àëi=1MSi‚àëj=1MSj‚Äã‚à•ùíõœµ‚àó‚àíùíõi‚à•‚©Ω‚àëi=1MSi‚àëj=1MSj‚Äã‚à•ùíõ‚àó‚àíùíõi‚à•+œµsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÄsubscriptùëÜùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÄsubscriptùëÜùëódelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùíõitalic-œµsubscriptùíõùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÄsubscriptùëÜùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÄsubscriptùëÜùëódelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùíõsubscriptùíõùëñitalic-œµ\displaystyle\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{M}\frac{S_{i}}{\sum_{j=1}^{M}S_{j}}\left\lVert\bm{z}_{\epsilon}^{*}-\bm{z}_{i}\right\rVert\leqslant\sum_{i=1}^{M}\frac{S_{i}}{\sum_{j=1}^{M}S_{j}}\left\lVert\bm{z}^{*}-\bm{z}_{i}\right\rVert+\epsilon (47)

which implies

‚àëi=1MŒ±i‚Äã‚à•ùíõœµ‚àó‚àíùíõi‚à•‚©Ω‚àëi=1MŒ±i‚Äã‚à•ùíõ‚àó‚àíùíõi‚à•+œµsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÄsubscriptùõºùëñdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùíõitalic-œµsubscriptùíõùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÄsubscriptùõºùëñdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùíõsubscriptùíõùëñitalic-œµ\displaystyle\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{M}\alpha_{i}\left\lVert\bm{z}_{\epsilon}^{*}-\bm{z}_{i}\right\rVert\leqslant\sum_{i=1}^{M}\alpha_{i}\left\lVert\bm{z}^{*}-\bm{z}_{i}\right\rVert+\epsilon (48)

by recalling the definition of Œ±isubscriptùõºùëñ\displaystyle\alpha_{i} as given in (17).

By the definition of geometric median, there is

‚àëi=1MŒ±i‚Äã‚à•ùíõ‚àó‚àíùíõi‚à•=infùíö‚àëi=1MŒ±i‚Äã‚à•ùíö‚àíùíõi‚à•‚©Ω‚àëi=1MŒ±i‚Äã‚à•ùíõi‚à•superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÄsubscriptùõºùëñdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùíõsubscriptùíõùëñsubscriptinfimumùíösuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÄsubscriptùõºùëñdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùíösubscriptùíõùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÄsubscriptùõºùëñdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùíõùëñ\displaystyle\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{M}\alpha_{i}\left\lVert\bm{z}^{*}-\bm{z}_{i}\right\rVert=\inf_{\bm{y}}\sum_{i=1}^{M}\alpha_{i}\left\lVert\bm{y}-\bm{z}_{i}\right\rVert\leqslant\sum_{i=1}^{M}\alpha_{i}\left\lVert\bm{z}_{i}\right\rVert (49)

According to the triangle inequality, we have

‚àëùíõi‚ààùíµ‚Ä≤Œ±i‚Äã‚à•ùíõœµ‚àó‚àíùíõi‚à•‚©æ‚àëùíõi‚ààùíµ‚Ä≤Œ±i‚Äã(‚à•ùíõi‚à•‚àí‚à•ùíõœµ‚àó‚à•)subscriptsubscriptùíõùëñsuperscriptùíµ‚Ä≤subscriptùõºùëñdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùíõitalic-œµsubscriptùíõùëñsubscriptsubscriptùíõùëñsuperscriptùíµ‚Ä≤subscriptùõºùëñdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùíõùëñdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùíõitalic-œµ\displaystyle\displaystyle\sum_{\bm{z}_{i}\in\mathcal{Z}^{{}^{\prime}}}\alpha_{i}\left\lVert\bm{z}_{\epsilon}^{*}-\bm{z}_{i}\right\rVert\geqslant\sum_{\bm{z}_{i}\in\mathcal{Z}^{{}^{\prime}}}\alpha_{i}\left(\left\lVert\bm{z}_{i}\right\rVert-\left\lVert\bm{z}_{\epsilon}^{*}\right\rVert\right) (50)
‚àëùíõi‚ààùíµ‚àñùíµ‚Ä≤Œ±i‚Äã‚à•ùíõœµ‚àó‚àíùíõi‚à•‚©æ‚àëùíõi‚ààùíµ‚àñùíµ‚Ä≤Œ±i‚Äã(‚à•ùíõœµ‚àó‚à•‚àí‚à•ùíõi‚à•)subscriptsubscriptùíõùëñùíµsuperscriptùíµ‚Ä≤subscriptùõºùëñdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùíõitalic-œµsubscriptùíõùëñsubscriptsubscriptùíõùëñùíµsuperscriptùíµ‚Ä≤subscriptùõºùëñdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùíõitalic-œµdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùíõùëñ\displaystyle\displaystyle\sum_{\bm{z}_{i}\in\mathcal{Z}\setminus\mathcal{Z}^{{}^{\prime}}}\alpha_{i}\left\lVert\bm{z}_{\epsilon}^{*}-\bm{z}_{i}\right\rVert\geqslant\sum_{\bm{z}_{i}\in\mathcal{Z}\setminus\mathcal{Z}^{{}^{\prime}}}\alpha_{i}\left(\left\lVert\bm{z}_{\epsilon}^{*}\right\rVert-\left\lVert\bm{z}_{i}\right\rVert\right) (51)

By adding (50) and (51) together, we obtain

‚àëùíõi‚ààùíµŒ±i‚Äã‚à•ùíõœµ‚àó‚àíùíõi‚à•subscriptsubscriptùíõùëñùíµsubscriptùõºùëñdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùíõitalic-œµsubscriptùíõùëñ\displaystyle\displaystyle\sum_{\bm{z}_{i}\in\mathcal{Z}}\alpha_{i}\left\lVert\bm{z}_{\epsilon}^{*}-\bm{z}_{i}\right\rVert ‚©æ‚àëùíõi‚ààùíµŒ±i‚Äã‚à•ùíõi‚à•+(1‚àí‚àëùíõi‚ààùíµ‚Ä≤2‚ÄãŒ±i)‚Äã‚à•ùíõœµ‚àó‚à•absentsubscriptsubscriptùíõùëñùíµsubscriptùõºùëñdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùíõùëñ1subscriptsubscriptùíõùëñsuperscriptùíµ‚Ä≤2subscriptùõºùëñdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùíõitalic-œµ\displaystyle\displaystyle\geqslant\sum_{\bm{z}_{i}\in\mathcal{Z}}\alpha_{i}\left\lVert\bm{z}_{i}\right\rVert+(1-\sum_{\bm{z}_{i}\in\mathcal{Z}^{{}^{\prime}}}2\alpha_{i})\left\lVert\bm{z}_{\epsilon}^{*}\right\rVert
‚àí2‚Äã‚àëùíõi‚ààùíµ‚àñùíµ‚Ä≤Œ±i‚Äã‚à•ùíõi‚à•2subscriptsubscriptùíõùëñùíµsuperscriptùíµ‚Ä≤subscriptùõºùëñdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùíõùëñ\displaystyle\displaystyle\quad-2\sum_{\bm{z}_{i}\in\mathcal{Z}\setminus\mathcal{Z}^{{}^{\prime}}}\alpha_{i}\left\lVert\bm{z}_{i}\right\rVert (52)

Combining (48), (49), and (52), and with the fact that ‚àëùíõi‚ààùíµ‚Ä≤Œ±i=1‚àíCŒ±<1/2subscriptsubscriptùíõùëñsuperscriptùíµ‚Ä≤subscriptùõºùëñ1subscriptùê∂ùõº12\displaystyle\sum_{\bm{z}_{i}\in\mathcal{Z}^{{}^{\prime}}}\alpha_{i}=1-C_{\alpha}<1/2, we have the following inequality

‚à•ùíõœµ‚àó‚à•‚©Ω2‚Äã‚àëùíõi‚ààùíµ‚àñùíµ‚Ä≤Œ±i‚Äã‚à•ùíõi‚à•+œµ1‚àí2‚Äã‚àëùíõi‚ààùíµ‚Ä≤Œ±idelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùíõitalic-œµ2subscriptsubscriptùíõùëñùíµsuperscriptùíµ‚Ä≤subscriptùõºùëñdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùíõùëñitalic-œµ12subscriptsubscriptùíõùëñsuperscriptùíµ‚Ä≤subscriptùõºùëñ\displaystyle\displaystyle\left\lVert\bm{z}_{\epsilon}^{*}\right\rVert\leqslant\frac{2\sum_{\bm{z}_{i}\in\mathcal{Z}\setminus\mathcal{Z}^{{}^{\prime}}}\alpha_{i}\left\lVert\bm{z}_{i}\right\rVert+\epsilon}{1-2\sum_{\bm{z}_{i}\in\mathcal{Z}^{{}^{\prime}}}\alpha_{i}} (53)

Squaring both sides of (53) and based on the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we further have

‚à•ùíõœµ‚àó‚à•2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùíõitalic-œµ2\displaystyle\displaystyle\quad\left\lVert\bm{z}_{\epsilon}^{*}\right\rVert^{2}

Taking the expectation of the both sides of (55) can lead to the statement of Lemma 3.
